{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3550986,"name":"billbo911","username":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T04:05:45.644Z","cooked":"

Currently, the way we have our coral manipulator configured, it uses a Minion motor to pull in the coral until a limit switch is hit. The limit switch is tied directly to the forward limit switch input on the Talon FXS. It works a treat.
So, now that we realized a properly inflated algae can also be gripped in the rollers, the behavior is less than desirable. It manipulator oscillates rapidly as the elasticity of the algae causes it to start pulling it out until the limit switch opens and the motor pulls it back in.

What we are wondering is, can the F/R limit switch be configured to not stop the motor, but be used as a flag to trigger a low power holding mode?

You can get the limit switch state regardless of whether it’s configured to stop to the motor.

Phoenix 6

Actuator Limits

CTR Electronics actuators, such as the TalonFX, support various kinds of hardware and software limits. Documentation on wiring limit switches can be found here. Retrieving Limit Switch State: The s...

Agreed, you can read the state of the switch, and thus act apon its states.

I guess the question is, can the behavior of the Limit Switch input be changed to not stop the motor from spinning when activated?

In the Talon FX configuration, you can disable the hardware limit switches

api.ctr-electronics.com

HardwareLimitSwitchConfigs (CTRE Phoenix 6 Java 25.3.0)

declaration: package: com.ctre.phoenix6.configs, class: HardwareLimitSwitchConfigs
